div.p: This paper deals with edge-preserving regularization for inverse problems in image processing. We first present a synthesis of the main results we have obtained in edge-preserving regularization by using a variational approach. We recall the model involving regularizing functions ' and we analyze the geometry-driven diffusion process of this model in the threedimensional (3-D) case. Then half-quadratic theorem is used to give a very simple reconstruction algorithm. After a critical analysis of this model, we propose another functional to minimize for the edge-preserving reconstruction purpose. It results in solving two coupled partial differential equations (PDE's): one processes the intensity, the other the edges. We study the relationship with similar PDE systems in particular with the functional proposed by Ambrosio-Tortorelli [1], [2] in order to approach the Mumford-Shah functional [3] developed in the segmentation application. Experimental results on synthetic and real images are presented.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: T HIS PAPER deals with edge-preserving regularization for inverse problems in image processing. During the last few years, much work has been done in nonlinear regularization for image reconstruction, often involving stochastic models such as Markov random fields (MRF's) [4]- [6], or variational approaches [1]- [3], [7]- [13] with partial differential equations (PDE's) [14]- [19]. The regularization of the inverse problem requires smoothing homogeneous areas of the object without degrading edges (which are an important attribute of the object). Clearly, the location of these edges are unknown and must be detected at the same time as the object is reconstructed and regularized.

In the second section of this paper, we analyze the main results that we have obtained in edge-preserving regularization using a variational approach [9]. We invoke the model involving regularizing functions , as well as the half-quadratic theorem which yields a very simple reconstruction algorithm. We then add an analysis of the geometry-driven diffusion process of this model in the three-dimensional (3-D) case.

In the next section of the paper, we propose a new functional minimization for edge-preserving reconstruction. In this case, two coupled PDE's must be solved: one dealing with image intensity and the other with the edges. We study the relationship with similar PDE systems already proposed by several authors [12], [13], [15], [18]. We also show the relationship between our model and the functional proposed by Ambrosio and Tortorelli [1], [2] in order to approximate the minimum of the Mumford-Shah functional [3] developed for segmentation applications. Finally, experimental results on synthetic and real images are given.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: This paper presents several minimization functionals for edge-preserving reconstruction. In this paper, we have proposed two algorithms and have shown by experimental results that regularizing the edges is very efficient. The coupled PDE's associated with the functionals are linked to the ones used by other authors. Using a variational approach for edge-preserving regularization naturally results in the elliptic functional proposed by Ambrosio and Tortorelli [1], [2] as an approximation to the Mumford-Shah segmentation functional. Perhaps this paper sheds new light on this approximation, via the different viewpoint of the half-quadratic regularization of [5], [9]. Current work is including to this coupled PDE system a segmentation based on the curve evolution theory [33].

div.head: Gilles
div.p: Michel Barlaud (M'88) was born in France on November 24, 1945. He received the Doctorat d'Etat degree from the University of Paris XII, France.

He is currently a Professor of image processing at Ecole Supèrieure en Sciences Informatiques, University of Nice-Sophia Antipolis, Nice, France. He is also Head of the Image Processing Group of the Laboratoire d'Informatique Signaux et Systèmes de Sophia Antipolis. His research interests are image compression using wavelets, lattice vector quantization, image restoration, segmentation, 2-D and 3-D reconstruction, and motion estimation. His contributions to the field include biorthogonal wavelengths, a method for counting lattice points on a pyramid, and a new edge adaptive quantization method.
